parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Prohibiting all fishing in Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) for 1 to over 25 years often corresponded with higher fish species richness in 14 site-comparison studies.
[Statement 2]: Six site-comparison studies found similar fish species richness between areas with and without fishing prohibitions.
[Statement 3]: One systematic review found no difference in fish species richness between areas with and without fishing prohibitions.
[Statement 4]: In seven studies, fish community composition in no-fishing areas differed from community composition in fished areas.
[Statement 5]: Thirty of 54 site-comparison studies and five of six reviews reported higher fish abundance or biomass in no-fishing Marine Protected Areas.
[Statement 6]: Eight studies found similar fish abundances between no-fishing Marine Protected Areas and fished areas.
[Statement 7]: Sixteen studies found mixed effects on fish abundance, with results varying by species, trophic level, size, duration, or habitat.
[Statement 8]: One study reported long-term declines of some sharks in areas where enforcement of fishing prohibitions was poor.
[Statement 9]: In Marine Protected Areas with zonation, no-fishing or no-entry zones had higher species numbers than partially fished zones and unprotected areas after 10 to 15 years.
[Statement 10]: No-fishing or no-entry zones had greater fish biomass or abundance than fished zones and outside areas after 3 to 27 years.
[Statement 11]: The effects of protection on fish biomass or abundance in zoned Marine Protected Areas varied by fish group, size, reef region, and protection level.

key: _gpt-5__What are the observed effects on fish abundance and diversity from prohibiting most or all fishing within Marine Protected Areas?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence indicates that modifying longline configuration can reduce unwanted shark and ray catches.
[Statement 2]: Increasing lead weight on mid-water longlines to increase the sinking rate reduced catches of unwanted sharks and rays.
[Statement 3]: Using nylon instead of wire hook attachments reduced unwanted shark and ray catches in some cases.
[Statement 4]: Deploying fishing gear at selected depths reduced unwanted catches of some shark and ray species in replicated studies.
[Statement 5]: Deploying fishing gear above the seabed instead of on the seabed reduced unwanted catches of some shark and ray species.

key: _gpt-5__Besides changing hook type in longline fisheries, what other gear modifications can reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence from North Sea studies indicates several trawl-gear modifications are available to reduce unwanted catches of cod and haddock.
[Statement 2]: A separator trawl separated unwanted cod into a lower codend.
[Statement 3]: The lower codend of the separator trawl had a larger mesh that allowed more smaller cod to escape.
[Statement 4]: Topless, or coverless, trawls reduced unwanted Atlantic cod.
[Statement 5]: Topless trawls reduced unwanted larger haddock but not smaller haddock.
[Statement 6]: In one of two cases, larger cod reductions occurred when using topless trawls.
[Statement 7]: Size-sorting escape grids fitted to trawl nets reduced unwanted sizes of cod and other non-target fish, including haddock, in multiple regions that include the North Sea.
[Statement 8]: In North Sea and Norwegian Sea studies, size-sorting escape grids improved size-selection for haddock.
[Statement 9]: In North Sea and Norwegian Sea studies, size-sorting escape grids did not consistently improve size-selection for cod.
[Statement 10]: One study found that size-sorting escape grids provided no improvement for cod size-selection compared to square-mesh windows.
[Statement 11]: Fitting mesh escape panels or windows to trawl nets reduced unwanted catches, including cod and haddock, in several North Sea studies.
[Statement 12]: Reviews and experiments reported that mesh escape panels improved size-selectivity for Atlantic cod and haddock.
[Statement 13]: The effects of mesh escape panels on selectivity varied by the panel's design and position.
[Statement 14]: Modifying the position and/or size of mesh escape panels improved size-selectivity for haddock in North Sea studies.
[Statement 15]: Some studies reported no reduction in unwanted cod when modifying the position or size of mesh escape panels.

key: _gpt-5__What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of cod and haddock in the North Sea?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across trawl fisheries, size-sorting escape grids frequently reduced unwanted fish catches.
[Statement 2]: Size-sorting escape grids sometimes improved size-selectivity in trawl fisheries.
[Statement 3]: In fish trawls, size-sorting escape grids reduced undersized or non-target catches in most studies.
[Statement 4]: Size-sorting escape grids improved size-selection for haddock in some cases but not for saithe or cod.
[Statement 5]: In one comparison, size-sorting escape grids did not outperform square-mesh escape windows.
[Statement 6]: In prawn and shrimp trawls, size-sorting escape grids often reduced unwanted fish, including sharks, across multiple regions.
[Statement 7]: The effects of size-sorting escape grids in prawn and shrimp trawls varied by species, site, year, and grid type.
[Statement 8]: Several studies on prawn and shrimp trawls found that grids caused no reduction in unwanted fish or had mixed outcomes.
[Statement 9]: Large, supported escape openings generally reduced unwanted fish and total unwanted catch in most trials.
[Statement 10]: Large, supported escape openings showed species-specific results, such as fewer unwanted Chinook salmon but mixed effects for widow rockfish.
[Statement 11]: One study reported that large, supported escape openings reduced unwanted sharks but not rays or sawfish compared to standard nets.
[Statement 12]: Mesh escape panels and windows showed mixed effects on selectivity.
[Statement 13]: Modifying the position or size of mesh escape panels sometimes improved size-selectivity for haddock and whiting.
[Statement 14]: The effects of mesh escape panels for cod were similar to standard trawls.
[Statement 15]: Reductions in unwanted catches using mesh escape panels were inconsistent across species and studies.
[Statement 16]: Combining different escape devices tended to enhance selectivity and bycatch reduction.
[Statement 17]: Combining mesh escape panels or windows with grids reduced unwanted fish, rays, sharks, and total discards in several studies.
[Statement 18]: The combination of mesh escape panels or windows with grids increased the size-selectivity of whiting.
[Statement 19]: When panels and grids were combined, escape occurred via either device depending on the species and size of the fish.
[Statement 20]: Combining size-sorting grids with large supported openings reduced unwanted fish and sharks/rays in most studies.
[Statement 21]: There were exceptions to the effectiveness of combining grids and large openings, with one study finding no reduction in sharks and another finding no reduction in sawfish.

key: _gpt-5__How do mesh escape panels, size-sorting grids, and large supported openings compare in their effectiveness at improving size-selectivity in trawl nets?
_gpt-5__What are the comparative effects on fish abundance of prohibiting all static fishing gear versus prohibiting only line fishing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A study in the Coral Sea found that areas closed to non-towed fishing gears had higher overall shark abundance when sampled with longlines compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted.
[Statement 2]: The same study in the Coral Sea found that areas closed to non-towed fishing gears did not have higher overall shark abundance when sampled with gillnets compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted.
[Statement 3]: A study in the Indian Ocean reported that closing a zone to offshore line fishing and all other boat-based fishing resulted in higher abundances of four fish species over-exploited by line fishing.
[Statement 4]: The higher abundances of over-exploited fish were found when comparing the closed zone to two zones where boat-based line and spear fishing were permitted.

[Statement 1]: Fish species richness was higher in no‑fishing/no‑access zones than in partially fished zones and unprotected areas 10 to 15 years after implementation.
[Statement 2]: The average lengths of several fish species were larger within no‑take zones than in partially fished zones three years after implementation.
[Statement 3]: Fish densities, biomass, and abundance were typically higher in non‑fished zones (no‑entry or no‑take) than in fished zones within the same protected areas.
[Statement 4]: The effects of zonation on fish populations varied among different fish groups, sizes, protection levels, and regions.
[Statement 5]: A zone closed to fishing but open to other recreation had a different fish age and sex structure than a multipurpose fished zone.
[Statement 6]: The zone closed to fishing and the multipurpose fished zone both had different fish age and sex structures compared to an unprotected low-exploitation site.
[Statement 7]: Tagged reef fishes were mostly recaptured near the sites where the fish were released.
[Statement 8]: Tagged reef fishes were mainly recaptured within zones where all or nearly all fishing was prohibited for up to 20 years.

key: _gpt-5__What are the outcomes for fish populations when marine protected areas are managed with zonation systems that permit some fishing?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across regions, reported outcomes from prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear vary.
[Statement 2]: In the Mediterranean, areas closed to all bottom-towed gears for 14 years showed higher biomass of adult red mullet compared to before the closure or to fished areas.
[Statement 3]: In the Mediterranean, areas closed to all bottom-towed gears for 14 years showed larger sizes of adult red mullet compared to before the closure or to fished areas.
[Statement 4]: In the Mediterranean, areas closed to all bottom-towed gears for 14 years showed increased recruitment of young red mullet compared to before the closure or to fished areas.
[Statement 5]: In the North Atlantic, an area closed to bottom trawling for seven years did not show higher recruitment or survival of young haddock compared to a trawled area.
[Statement 6]: Other closures in the North Atlantic that prohibited mobile and static bottom gears for 5–15 years reported cod with better growth than in openly fished areas.
[Statement 7]: Other closures in the North Atlantic that prohibited mobile and static bottom gears for 5–15 years reported higher numbers of larger and older cod individuals than in openly fished areas.
[Statement 8]: For benthic invertebrates, North Sea sites closed to trawling for 15 years had a different community composition than trawled sites.
[Statement 9]: North Sea sites closed to trawling for 15 years had higher diversity of benthic invertebrates than trawled sites.
[Statement 10]: One study found that Mediterranean sites closed for 20 years had a different benthic invertebrate composition compared to trawled sites.
[Statement 11]: One study of Mediterranean sites closed for 20 years showed no differences in overall invertebrate diversity or abundance compared to trawled sites.
[Statement 12]: Evidence from studies across multiple regions, including the Indian Ocean, indicates that effects on fish size in areas prohibiting bottom-towed gears varied between fish groups.
[Statement 13]: Evidence from studies across multiple regions, including the Indian Ocean, indicates that effects on fish size in areas prohibiting bottom-towed gears varied with habitat type.
[Statement 14]: In some cases, closures prohibiting bottom-towed gears had no effect on average fish weight.
[Statement 15]: In some cases, closures prohibiting bottom-towed gears had no effect on combined fish and invertebrate sizes.

key: _gpt-5__How does the effectiveness of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear vary between the North Atlantic and other regions like the Mediterranean or Indian Ocean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Topless (coverless) trawls and separator trawls both show evidence of reducing unwanted fish.
[Statement 2]: The effectiveness of topless and separator trawls in reducing unwanted fish differs in consistency and context.
[Statement 3]: For topless trawls, four replicated, controlled studies reported mixed but often positive effects.
[Statement 4]: Topless trawls reduced catches of unwanted Atlantic cod in some trials.
[Statement 5]: Topless trawls reduced discards of commercial species in some trials.
[Statement 6]: Topless trawls resulted in size-dependent reductions for haddock, where larger fish were reduced but smaller fish were not.
[Statement 7]: In another case, topless trawls caused reductions for only one of four commercial species.
[Statement 8]: For separator trawls, two studies reported targeted reductions of unwanted fish via gear design.
[Statement 9]: One randomized North Sea study showed unwanted cod were directed into a lower codend with larger mesh.
[Statement 10]: The larger mesh in the separator trawl allowed more smaller cod to escape.
[Statement 11]: An Atlantic study found that adding a square-mesh escape panel to a separator trawl reduced catches of one of two unwanted fish species in a crustacean fishery.
[Statement 12]: Overall, topless trawls show mixed reductions of unwanted fish across species and sizes.
[Statement 13]: Separator trawls demonstrate design-mediated separation that reduced some unwanted species or sizes in specific configurations.

key: _gpt-5__How do separator trawls and topless trawls compare in their effectiveness at reducing unwanted fish catch?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Modifying trap and pot configurations was evaluated for effects on marine fish across 23 studies in multiple regions.
[Statement 2]: One replicated, controlled study found the survival of small herring that escaped through a size‑sorting grid was similar to the survival of trap‑caught herring that did not pass through a grid.
[Statement 3]: Sixteen of 20 replicated studies reported that configuration changes, such as different trap types, larger mesh, or escape devices, reduced unwanted catches of fish overall or for specific species.
[Statement 4]: Configuration changes reduced unwanted catches of species including brown trout, black sea bass, herring, bluethroat wrasse and leatherjacket, cod, protected rockfishes, whitefish, American eel, winter flounder, and sharks/rays.
[Statement 5]: Three studies found that trap or pot configuration changes did not reduce catches for some species, such as white croaker, non‑commercial fish, and undersized Atlantic cod.
[Statement 6]: One study reported that configuration changes increased catches of non-target haddock.
[Statement 7]: One study noted that creels did not catch high proportions of immature fish compared to bottom trawls.
[Statement 8]: Size‑selectivity improved in three of four replicated studies when traps or pots had square‑mesh escape windows or larger mesh.
[Statement 9]: Improved size-selectivity from modified traps or pots benefited Atlantic cod, black sea bass, and most fish species.
[Statement 10]: One study found that using square-mesh escape windows or larger mesh had no effect on size-selectivity for panga.
[Statement 11]: Modifications to trap- or bag-nets designed to exclude mammals reduced seal damage to salmon catches.
[Statement 12]: Modifications to trap- or bag-nets designed to exclude mammals led to higher catches of undamaged salmon.
[Statement 13]: Modifications to trap- or bag-nets designed to exclude mammals did not lead to higher catches of undamaged whitefish.

key: _gpt-5__What are the documented effects of modifying fishing trap or pot configurations on marine fish?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Nine studies tested electropositive deterrents on fishing gear.
[Statement 2]: The studies on electropositive deterrents spanned the Atlantic Ocean, Gulf of Alaska, South Pacific Ocean and Tasman Sea.
[Statement 3]: The research into electropositive deterrents on fishing gear also included two laboratory studies and one global systematic review.
[Statement 4]: Behavioural evidence from three of four replicated studies showed reduced feeding attempts or bait consumption by spiny dogfish, great hammerhead and draughtboard sharks when deterrent materials were attached near bait.
[Statement 5]: One study found no reduction in feeding attempts or bait consumption for bonnethead and young lemon sharks when deterrent materials were attached near bait.
[Statement 6]: One study reported no effect on bait consumption by commercially valuable Pacific halibut when deterrent materials were attached near bait.
[Statement 7]: Catch outcomes from two of four replicated, controlled field studies reported fewer unwanted catches of spiny dogfish, longnose skate, and combined sharks and rays on longlines and traps when electropositive deterrents were used.
[Statement 8]: Catch outcomes from two of four replicated, controlled field studies also reported fewer undersized halibut when electropositive deterrents were used versus standard or non-deterrent gear.
[Statement 9]: Two other field studies found no reduction in catches, with catches of spiny dogfish, total sharks, blue shark, and combined sharks and rays being similar to controls.
[Statement 10]: A global systematic review found no reduction in catches of spiny dogfish, total sharks, blue shark, and combined sharks and rays when using electropositive deterrents compared to controls.

key: _gpt-5__What is the evidence for using electropositive deterrents on fishing gear to reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In replicated, controlled studies across European seas, 10 out of 16 studies reported that square mesh codends reduced unwanted catch of non-target or discarded fish and invertebrates.
[Statement 2]: Four of 16 replicated, controlled studies in European seas found no reduction in unwanted catch when using square mesh codends.
[Statement 3]: One study in European seas found that square mesh codends retained more fish overall.
[Statement 4]: One study found that the amount of unwanted catch depended on both mesh size and configuration.
[Statement 5]: In studies where square mesh codends showed no or varied effects, increasing the mesh size improved selectivity for both square and diamond mesh codend types.
[Statement 6]: In the English Channel, one replicated study found a square mesh codend caught fewer non-commercial invertebrates in one of two areas.
[Statement 7]: In the English Channel, one replicated study found a square mesh codend caught similar amounts of non-commercial invertebrates in the other of two areas.
[Statement 8]: Adding square-mesh escape panels to a square mesh codend reduced the numbers of discarded finfish in the English Channel.
[Statement 9]: Adding square-mesh escape panels to a square mesh codend reduced non-commercial invertebrate bycatch in the English Channel.

[Statement 1]: Seven site comparison studies found that marine protected areas where all fishing had been prohibited for 3–16 years had a different fish community composition compared to fished areas.
[Statement 2]: 14 of 20 site comparison studies found higher fish species richness in non-fished marine protected areas 1 to >25 years after implementation compared to fished areas.
[Statement 3]: Six site comparison studies found similar fish species richness between non-fished marine protected areas and fished areas.
[Statement 4]: One systematic review in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans found no difference in fish species richness between non-fished marine protected areas and fished areas.
[Statement 5]: One replicated study in the Indian Ocean reported that effects on fish species richness after 15 years varied with the sampling method used.
[Statement 6]: One site comparison study found lower total fish species richness in marine protected areas in the Caribbean Sea that were closed to all fishing with limited exceptions for up to seven years, when compared to unprotected areas.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In six of fourteen replicated, controlled studies, using a square mesh codend improved size selectivity.
[Statement 2]: The improvement in size selectivity from a square mesh codend was observed for species such as silver hake, horse mackerel, European hake, axillary seabream, poor cod, greater forkbeard, and blue whiting.
[Statement 3]: Using a square mesh codend showed no difference in size selectivity in five of fourteen replicated, controlled studies.
[Statement 4]: Species for which using a square mesh codend showed no difference in selectivity include Atlantic mackerel, long rough dab, yellowtail scad, striped seapike, rockfish, and flatfish.
[Statement 5]: The effect of using a square mesh codend on size selectivity varied with body shape in three of fourteen replicated, controlled studies.
[Statement 6]: In studies where the effect of a square mesh codend varied, selectivity improved for roundfish but not for at least one flatfish.
[Statement 7]: Some studies reported that increasing mesh size raised size selectivity for both square and diamond meshes.
[Statement 8]: Turning a diamond mesh by 90° improved size selection for cod, red mullet, common pandora, and round-bodied fish in a review and four of five replicated, controlled studies.
[Statement 9]: Turning a diamond mesh by 90° did not improve size selection for plaice, annular sea bream, and flatfish.
[Statement 10]: One study found that turning a diamond mesh by 90° resulted in no improvement in size selection for cod, plaice, and flounder.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In the Tasman Sea, a study reported that fish assemblage/species composition changed after prohibiting all commercial fishing in an estuary over two years.
[Statement 2]: In the South Atlantic Ocean, a study found no change in species composition between a reserve closed to all commercial fishing for 40 years and unprotected fished areas.

[Statement 1]: Across 54 site comparison studies, 30 found higher fish abundances (density and/or biomass) inside marine protected areas where all fishing was prohibited for up to 25 years or more, compared to fished areas.
[Statement 2]: Five of six reviews reported higher fish abundances in non-fished marine reserves with 1–27 years of protection, compared to fished areas.
[Statement 3]: Eight studies reported similar abundances between protected and fished areas 1–20 years after prohibiting fishing.
[Statement 4]: Sixteen studies reported effects that varied among species or groups after 3–20 years of protection.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two worldwide systematic reviews examined fisheries under catch share systems.
[Statement 2]: One review found that fisheries or stocks managed under catch shares were more likely to meet management target levels for biomass sustainability.
[Statement 3]: Another review found no difference in the performance of biomass-based management targets between fisheries under catch shares, fleet-wide catch caps, or fishing effort controls.
[Statement 4]: Two worldwide systematic reviews reported that catch share fisheries had lower rates of over-exploitation than non-catch share fisheries.
[Statement 5]: Two worldwide systematic reviews reported that a higher proportion of catch share fisheries met or exceeded management target levels for rates of exploitation.
[Statement 6]: A global systematic review reported that fisheries with fleet-wide catch quotas were no different to those managed by catch shares or effort controls in terms of reaching biomass-based management targets.
[Statement 7]: A global systematic review reported that fewer catch quota stocks were over-exploited than those with effort controls.
[Statement 8]: A global systematic review reported that fewer catch share fisheries stocks were over-exploited than those with effort controls.

key: _gpt-5__What is the evidence from global reviews on the effectiveness of catch share systems for managing fish stocks sustainably?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A before-and-after, site comparison in the Atlantic found no increase in spawning stock biomass, survival, or length composition of cod over nine years following a temporary closure compared to fished areas.
[Statement 2]: A Northeast Atlantic tagging study reported adult cod spent nearly a third of their time inside a seasonally closed spawning area during its implementation.
[Statement 3]: In the North Sea, fixed temporary closures had little effect on cod fishing effort.
[Statement 4]: In the North Sea, real-time area closures reduced the annual amount of cod caught, including both retained and discarded fish.
[Statement 5]: In targeted fisheries, catch rates of red mullet and total catch of fish and invertebrates combined increased after temporary closures over 10 years.
[Statement 6]: The catch rates for European hake did not increase after temporary closures over 10 years in targeted fisheries.
[Statement 7]: An Atlantic before-and-after, site comparison found no change in cod catches over nine years of temporary closures.
[Statement 8]: During a grouper closure, spear-fisher catches of herbivores increased, indicating a shift in targeting.
[Statement 9]: Replicated before-and-after work in the Norwegian Sea found higher weights of young salmon after the long-term closure of a commercial coastal fishery.
[Statement 10]: Replicated before-and-after work in the Norwegian Sea found similar or lower weights of older salmon after the long-term closure of a commercial coastal fishery.
[Statement 11]: After the long-term closure of a commercial coastal fishery in the Norwegian Sea, more young salmon returned to rivers compared to before the closure.
[Statement 12]: After the long-term closure of a commercial coastal fishery in the Norwegian Sea, a similar number of older salmon returned to rivers compared to before the closure.
[Statement 13]: Site comparisons found higher abundance for only one of seven species inside year-round groundfish closures of six to eight years.
[Statement 14]: Site comparisons found lower monkfish abundance inside year-round groundfish closures of six to eight years.
[Statement 15]: In the North Sea, lesser sandeel biomass and density peaked but did not show an overall increase three years after a long-term closure.
[Statement 16]: In the North Sea, annual sandeel catches varied after an indefinite closure was implemented.
[Statement 17]: Inside an area closed to customary fishing for eight years, six of seven species had a reduced flight response distance.
[Statement 18]: Unwanted cod catch was reduced where long-term closures were combined with gear-limited areas.
[Statement 19]: Overall fishing effort for lesser sandeel was reduced by long-term closures.

_gpt-5__What are the observed effects of fitting deterrents, such as lights or electropositive materials, to fishing gear?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Electropositive deterrents attached to fishing gear sometimes reduced unwanted catches of sharks, rays, spiny dogfish, and undersized halibut.
[Statement 2]: Several studies and a systematic review reported that unwanted catch rates were similar for gear with and without electropositive deterrents.
[Statement 3]: Some shark species showed reduced feeding attempts and bait consumption near electropositive deterrents.
[Statement 4]: Other shark species did not show reduced feeding attempts or bait consumption near electropositive deterrents.
[Statement 5]: Halibut feeding was unaffected by electropositive deterrents.
[Statement 6]: Adding artificial lights to gear reduced unwanted fish in shrimp trawls when the lights were fitted to the fishing line.
[Statement 7]: Adding artificial lights to a size-sorting grid on shrimp trawls did not reduce unwanted fish catches.
[Statement 8]: Artificial lights attached to a size-sorting grid did not improve size-selectivity for several fish species.
[Statement 9]: For reptiles, attaching lights to gillnets reduced green and loggerhead turtle bycatch in multiple studies.
[Statement 10]: One study reported no loggerhead turtle mortalities in nets lit with UV lights, while some mortalities occurred in unlit nets.
[Statement 11]: Increasing the number of light sticks on longlines had mixed effects on loggerhead and leatherback turtle catch rates.
[Statement 12]: Visual deterrents, such as floating shark shapes, on gillnets reduced green turtle catch in one study.
[Statement 13]: Captive tests of visual deterrents showed mixed behavioural responses from turtles to shark-shaped and spherical deterrents.

[Statement 1]: Prohibiting all fishing in no-take marine protected areas (MPAs) is associated in many cases with higher fish abundance and biomass.
[Statement 2]: No-take MPAs are associated with higher species richness and larger fish sizes.
[Statement 3]: Prohibiting fishing in marine protected areas is associated with increased egg production for targeted species.
[Statement 4]: Protected areas see greater use by sharks and commercially important reef fishes when all fishing is prohibited.
[Statement 5]: Prohibiting fishing in marine protected areas is associated with reduced fishing mortality for tagged fishes and higher stock biomass.
[Statement 6]: No-take MPAs can sometimes lead to elevated catch rates near their boundaries.
[Statement 7]: The effects of no-take MPAs can vary by species, habitat, and enforcement.
[Statement 8]: Protecting spawning fish from capture through seasonal or permanent closures shows mixed population outcomes.
[Statement 9]: A North Atlantic comparison found no increase in cod spawning stock biomass, survival, or size over nine years of closures.
[Statement 10]: The North Atlantic comparison also found no change in commercial catches over a nine-year period.
[Statement 11]: Tracking showed substantial use of closed spawning and nursery areas by cod and juvenile sharks.
[Statement 12]: A seasonal grouper closure shifted spear-fishing effort toward herbivores.
[Statement 13]: One Atlantic study showed that establishing temporary fishery closures resulted in no cod biomass, survival, or size increase over nine years.
[Statement 14]: Tagged cod spent about one-third of their time inside a seasonal spawning closure while it was implemented.
[Statement 15]: Real-time area closures reduced the annual amount of cod caught.
[Statement 16]: Some targeted fisheries showed increased catch rates after temporary closures ended.
[Statement 17]: Areas that allow only periodic fishing had greater fish biomass than areas that were openly fished.
[Statement 18]: Areas with periodic fishing had fish biomass similar to that of permanently closed areas.
[Statement 19]: Over periods of 18 months to six years, areas with periodic fishing had higher catch rates than openly fished areas.

key: _gpt-5__What are the most effective spatial management actions for protecting spawning fish and their habitats?
_gpt-5__How does the effectiveness of no-take marine protected areas on fish communities differ between the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across studies of no-take marine protected areas, 15 studies were conducted in the Indian Ocean.
[Statement 2]: Across studies of no-take marine protected areas, 12 studies were conducted in the Mediterranean Sea.
[Statement 3]: In both the Indian Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea, site comparisons reported different fish community composition in no-take areas versus fished areas after 3–16 years.
[Statement 4]: Studies of no-take areas in both the Indian Ocean and Mediterranean Sea often found higher species richness in no-take areas.
[Statement 5]: One replicated Indian Ocean study found the effect of no-take areas on species richness/diversity after 15 years varied with the sampling method used.
[Statement 6]: Multiple studies across the Mediterranean and Indian Oceans reported higher fish abundance or biomass in no-take areas.
[Statement 7]: Other studies found that the effects of no-take areas on fish abundance were similar or mixed depending on species, trophic position, size, habitat, or protection duration.
[Statement 8]: A region-specific finding in the Mediterranean was the presence of more eggs of four commercially targeted fish species inside a no-take reserve enforced for three years.
[Statement 9]: A region-specific finding in the Mediterranean was higher small-scale commercial catch rates closest to a 22-year no-take reserve, with catch rates decreasing with distance.
[Statement 10]: A region-specific finding in the Indian Ocean was higher fish grazing rates in no-take areas protected for 1 and 24 years.
[Statement 11]: A region-specific finding in the Indian Ocean was the highest reef-fish stock biomass in enforced no-take areas compared to other management regimes.
[Statement 12]: A region-specific finding in the Indian Ocean was that most individuals of five fish species remained within a no-take reserve over nine years.
